Exaggerate: The claim may be considered an exaggeration because it states that "one in three women is sexually assaulted," without providing sufficient evidence or statistical data to support this specific figure.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is limited data available to accurately determine the percentage of women who have been sexually assaulted during their journey to the United States.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all women who make the journey north are at risk of being sexually assaulted, without acknowledging that not all women may face the same level of danger or risk.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the reported statistics, such as the possibility that the reported cases of sexual assault are not solely attributed to the journey north, but also include incidents occurring within the United States or other locations.
Understate: It is possible that the claim understates the actual number of women who have been sexually assaulted during their journey north, as the available data may not capture the full extent of the problem due to underreporting or limited access to information.
Falters at times: The claim may falter at times in terms of providing a clear and accurate representation of the prevalence of sexual assault among women on the dangerous journey north, due to the lack of comprehensive data and varying sources with conflicting figures.
Contradict fact: The claim may contradict fact if it is found that the reported figure of "one in three women" being sexually assaulted is significantly different from the actual rate of sexual assault experienced by women on the journey north.
